dataset.title: Post-fire recovery in the 2004 burns of interior Alaska: Densities of tree seedlings measured in 2008 by Joint Fire Science Program

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology; University of Saskatchewan; 112 Science Place

abstract.para: This dataset contains seedling densities measured in control (unseeded) plots in 90 sites within the 2004 burns of interior Alaska. Data are presented as seedling densities per sq. m. All sites were in communities dominated by black spruce before burning, and were located 100 to 600 m from the road, beyond the range of any visible road effects and away from any signs of other human disturbance.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: corrections
section.para: Data were quality- and error-checked by Jill Johnstone when compiling the site-level summaries.

section.title: Methods
section.para: Each site was sampled as a 30x30 m area (~0.01 ha). In June 2008, the start of the fourth growing season after the 2004 fires, we surveyed all sites for newly established seedlings of post-fire origin. Seedlings were counted in 20, 50x50 cm quadrats for a total sample area of 5 m^2 per study site. Quadrat locations were determined by repeated, "blind" tossing of a quadrat, or were laid out at random points along parallel transects in a subset of 39 intensive study sites. The number and species of all post-fire seedlings were recorded in each quadrat, including resprouting stems. Seedling counts were averaged and standardized by unit area to obtain one estimate of average seedling density for each species at a site.

dataTable.entityDescription: This dataset contains seedling densities measured in control (unseeded) plots in 90 sites within the 2004 burns of interior Alaska.

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique site number assigned to each plot (values are between 1 and 92).

textDomain.definition: A unique site number assigned to each plot (values are between 1 and 92).

attribute.attributeDefinition: Each site is designated as an intensive or extensive study site. Quadrat sampling was haphazard for extensive sites and stratified random for intensive sites.

Density of live, post-fire spruce (Picea mariana) seedlings per square meter. All seedlings were assumed to be black spruce. Detailed assessment of needle morphology (resin canals) of 20 spruce seedlings from a subset of 6 sites showed no white spruce seedlings.
Density of live, post-fire aspen (Populus tremuloides) seedlings per square meter. Seedlings arising from seed or resprouting are included together. Most seedlings originated from seed.
Density of live, post-fire birch (Betula neoalaskana) seedlings per square meter. At some sites, it is possible that seedlings were hybrids of Betula neoalaskana x glandulosa.
